channel.title: Learn audio DSP video series
channel.description:
Dan Prince has just started a new video series which might interest a few here. basic starting, and introducing Octave which is like an open source matlab which is useful for modelling.
go check it out, and give him some feedback/encouragement to continue the series :)
https://youtu.be/tx_cjBjZ2zM
here is how Dan described it on KVR
> In an effort to force myself to practice audio DSP algorithms, I have started putting together a video tutorial series where I explain the basics of audio DSP. I am aiming to teach music technology enthusiasts and other curious people just enough DSP for them to really get how common effects and synthesizers work by doing some mathematical hand waving, and pointing to relevant references for those interested in getting more theoretical. I think there is a real gap in the literature between Max/MSP level of technical detail and books that presume a degree in EE that I am hoping to fill with these videos by making them inviting to not-as-technical people.
> I have many more ideas for videos in the future where I want to cover waveform generation, delay, modulation effects, distortion and non-linear effects, etc. I would love to hear your feedback on this first lesson!

item.title: Learn audio DSP video series

item.title: Learn audio DSP video series
item.dc:creator: @Gavin Gavin
item.description:
@Gavin wrote:

Awesome, I have my Octave installed, ready to go !
Just a thought, maybe we can have discussions on the video, to help fill in any gaps, and what would also be really cool is how to transfer and apply it and make it work in the objects within Axo environment.

Read full topic

item.title: Learn audio DSP video series
item.dc:creator: @thetechnobear Mark Harris
item.description:
@thetechnobear wrote:

Dan Prince has just started a new video series which might interest a few here.
basic starting, and introducing Octave which is like an open source matlab which is useful for modelling.

go check it out, and give him some feedback/encouragement to continue the series

here is how Dan described it on KVR

In an effort to force myself to practice audio DSP algorithms, I have started putting together a video tutorial series where I explain the basics of audio DSP. I am aiming to teach music technology enthusiasts and other curious people just enough DSP for them to really get how common effects and synthesizers work by doing some mathematical hand waving, and pointing to relevant references for those interested in getting more theoretical. I think there is a real gap in the literature between Max/MSP level of technical detail and books that presume a degree in EE that I am hoping to fill with these videos by making them inviting to not-as-technical people.

I have many more ideas for videos in the future where I want to cover waveform generation, delay, modulation effects, distortion and non-linear effects, etc. I would love to hear your feedback on this first lesson!

Read full topic
